subNodes.conversationText: "I am the beast above the house of glory, Shaking the pointed splendors of my crown Against your nothingness, that which is Against your abject never-to-become."

"The objects of your striving are so small,
The prizes baffling and despicable!"

"Why attempt to rise above the roar
Of all your dismal equals, clamoring
To make a name the vast unlettered void
Will swallow with your life? Kneel, child of death,
To might, that deference might spare you from
Despair."

"A witch? A mewling wretch. You fail the test.
Your name will unremembered be. Glory
Studies glory out of spite and never
Bows to it. Yet here you are, and I
Must work with such material. Climb up
My flank so I can hear your wheedling words."

The beast was very big, but climbing did not look too hard, as long as it didn't decide to suddenly shake its great head. Ridges in its armor and thick tufts of fur would offer handholds and footholds. Knott became a normal gourd, and <FirstName> stowed it away.
At first, the climb was easy. <FirstName> rose almost spider-like up the breastplate while Pharaoh, excited to see the young witch joining him up high, flew circles around <him/her>.

The higher <he/she> got, though, the harder it was. The beast's armor, slick with mountain mists, stopped offering sure holds, and, once, <he/she> slipped and fell a foot or two. <He/She> was saved only by the luck of having found a crack in the armor with <his/her> flailing arms.

Finally, the young witch stood about halfway up the creature's side, right under what would have been the armpit of a human. <He/She> had two ways forward. <He/She> could attempt climbing the beast's pauldron, though this would likely require even more strength from <his/her> trembling limbs, or <he/she> could attempt to jump for one of the tassels that decorated the top of the breastplate -- though missing it would likely prove fatal.

[Success: Strength 15] The lamellar plates of the pauldron were wet and treacherous, but with a little ingenuity and a burst of strength the young witch was able to hoist <him/her>self over them and onto surer territory.
<He/She> climbed the rest of the way without trouble and soon stood in the scruffy crook between its neck and shoulder.

Now <he/she> could look down. <He/She> had come much higher than <he/she> thought. The mountain and forest encircling it stretched out in miniature below, but even as <he/she> gazed at it the landscape receded behind a veil of clouds.

[Failure: Strength too low] <He/She> didn't climb for long. The lamellar plates of the pauldron were wet and treacherous and offered nothing for <him/her> to grasp. <He/She> slid down one and off the beast's shoulder into thin air. Pharaoh shrieked.
[Success: Dexterity 15] <He/She> caught it with one hand, and the other quickly followed. Then <he/she> shimmied up the makeshift rope, not daring to look down at the thousand rocks below.
[Failure: Dexterity too low] <He/She> caught only air. Pharaoh shrieked.

<He/She> fell -- and then <he/she> stopped falling. The spirit's magic lifted <him/her> into the air -- but even as it did, the flask of blood <he/she>'d collected from the hunter fell out of <his/her> pack and shattered on the rocks below.

<He/She> fell -- and then <he/she> stopped falling. The spirit's magic lifted <him/her> into the air -- but even as it did, the flask of blood <he/she>'d collected from the second hunter fell out of <his/her> pack and shattered on the rocks below.

<He/She> fell -- and then <he/she> stopped falling. The spirit's magic lifted <him/her> into the air -- but even as it did, the flask of blood <he/she>'d collected from the second hunter fell out of <his/her> pack and shattered on the rocks below.
<He/She> fell -- and then <he/she> stopped falling. The spirit's magic lifted <him/her> into the air.

"Foolish little flea. You test the air
And find it wanting, eh? No matter, flea:
Stand here where it's safe."
The beast's magic set the young witch down in the scruffy crook between its neck and shoulder.

Now <he/she> could look down. <He/She> had come much higher than <he/she> thought. The mountain and forest encircling it stretched out in miniature below, but even as <he/she> gazed at it the landscape receded behind a veil of clouds.

The beast was very big, but climbing did not look too hard, as long as it didn't decide to suddenly shake itself. Ridges in its armor and thick tufts of fur would offer handholds and footholds. There were even tassels on its breastplate that might serve as ropes.

<FirstName> felt compelled to try it. <He/She> didn't know why. Knott became a normal gourd. The young witch stowed him away without a second thought.

"Good, good! This witch will not be bent by words.
Glory studies glory out of spite
And never bows to it. Climb up my flank
And let me hear what boon you've come to ask."
